name: 餐旅經營管理研究
description:
This is an advanced-level course that covers complex issues facing hospitality industry leaders today. This course will prepare students to become entry-level
managers in the hospitality industry by exposing them to contemporary operational issues and situations, equipping them with various problem solving methods and teaching them to develop and implement strategic
solutions. Topics covered include guest service, leadership, strategic planning, trends and technology, communication, marketing, human resource management, and crisis management. Class content is delivered
through lectures, group discussion, learning activities, and case studies.
goals: Evaluate the trends toward internationalization of hospitality industry.
Explain the nature of hospitality service in the global market.
Describe the opportunities of hospitality organizations to expand globally
Stress the importance of the customer in the design and running of a hospitality operation.
Demonstrate the importance of the concept and location of hospitality operations.
Review the key control areas of the management of hospitality systems.
Tie together the various courses in the curriculum into the development of a business plan and operational procedures for hospitality operations
syllabus:
_**Week 1 – Introduction to the Course (3/5) (+** **Group Formation)**_

_**W****eek 2 –** **Introduction to Hospitality Management** **(3/12) + Key topics to learn**_

_**W****eek 3 – Understanding** **Trends** **in Hospitality Management Research (+ How to Identify Trends) (3/19)**_

1.  Paper – Ryan, C. (2015). Trends in hospitality management research: a personal reflection. _International Journal of Contemporary Hospitality Management_, _27_(3), 340-361.

_**W****eek 4 –** **Service Quality Management (SQM)** **(+ Service Quality Dimensions) (3/26)**_

1.  Paper – Dedeoğlu, B. B., & Demirer, H. (2015). Differences in service quality perceptions of stakeholders in the hotel industry. _International Journal of Contemporary Hospitality Management_, _27_(1), 130-146.

_**W****eek 5 – Holiday – No Lecture** **(4/2)**_

_**W****eek 8 – Customer** **Experience Design (CXD)** **(4/23)**_

1.  Case Study – Broderick, Bing. (2017). Food with Purpose: Dudley Dough and Haley House Bakery Café _Managing for Social Impact_ (pp. 73-86): Springer.

_**Week 10 –** **Guest Talk (Social Enterprise Restaurant)****\*** **(5/7)** (\* topic and date to be confirmed)_

**_W_****_eek_** **_11_** **_– Group Project Proposal Presentations_** **_(5/14)_** **_(All Groups)_**

_**W****eek** **12** **–** **Environmental Strategies** **in the Hotels & Restaurants (5/21)**_

2.  Paper – Kasim, A., & Ismail, A. (2012). Environmentally friendly practices among restaurants: drivers and barriers to change. _Journal of Sustainable Tourism_, _20_(4), 551-570.

**Week 13 – Product Innovation Process (PIP) in Restaurant Chains (5/28)**

1.  Paper – Ottenbacher, M. C., & Harrington, R. J. (2009). The product innovation process of quick-service restaurant chains. _International Journal of Contemporary Hospitality Management_, _21_(5), 523-541.

_**W****eek** **1****4 –** **Restaurant Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and Menu Analysis** **(6/4)**_

2.  Paper – Taylor, J. J., & Brown, D. M. (2007). Menu analysis: A review of techniques and approaches. Hospitality Review, 25(2), 6.

_**W****eek** **15** **–** **Human Resource Management (HRM) Issues in Hospitality Businesses** **(6/11)**_

_**W****eek** **16** **– Group** **Project Presentations** **(6/18) (All G****roups)**_

_**W****eek** **17** **– Field Trip / Field Studies** (\* to be conducted by students)_

_**W****eek** **18** **– Field** **S****tudies** (\* to be conducted by students)_
